Sentencas: The morphology of layers of fully yttria-stabilised zirconia (YSZ) deposited by reactive magnetron sputtering was studied with regard to their application as thin electrolytes for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC).
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: A thin layer of YSZ was deposited on top of anode substrates for SOFC.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: The substrate comprises the warm-pressed anode itself, which supports the complete cell, and an anode functional layer deposited by vacuum slip casting, which is in direct contact with the electrolyte.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: From previous experiments it is known that non-assisted reactive DC magnetron sputtering produces layers with rather high leak-rate even when depositing at high temperatures.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: Residual pores on the substrates' surfaces are responsible for the incomplete coverage by the thin electrolyte and are detrimental to the cell's performance.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: In the present paper, the effect of increasing bias power applied to the substrate is studied.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: A clear improvement of the layer morphology and gas-tightness can be observed with increasing bias power.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering

Sentencas: SOFC single cell-tests show art improved performance with regard to standard wet-ceramic processing routes.
Titulo: Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering
Dense yttria-stabilised zirconia electrolyte layers for SOFC by reactive magnetron sputtering
